clinical_study.brief_title: Pharmacologic and Psychological Interventions for Pediatric Pain During Venipuncture.
clinical_study.official_title: Pharmacologic and Psychological Interventions for Pediatric Pain During Venipuncture：a Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess the efficacy of topical anesthetic combined with psychological interventions for pain control due to peripheral venipuncture in children and adolescents.

detailed_description.textblock:
Intravenous infusion is the main route of drug administration for hospitalized children. Therefore, venipuncture has become a major source of pain. Without pain management can lead to moderate to severe pain and can cause fear, tension and anxiety in children. The current pain relief form include pharmacologic(i.e. topical anesthetic) and psychological(i.e. distraction) interventions. Psychological interventions are not as good as pharmacologic methods in terms of pain relief, but it is more conducive to relieve children's distress reactions such as fear and anxiety. There are less high qualified evidences supporting that pharmacologic combined with psychological interventions can enhance children's abilities to cope with painful procedures successfully. The hypothesis of the current study is that topical anesthetic combined with psychological interventions can decrease children's pain and distress.
The current study adopts a randomized, blind, controlled intervention trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to three groups: a lidocaine group, a psychological interventions group, or a combined group(lidocaine plus psychological interventions). The outcomes include self-reported pain, observer-reported pain, salivary cortisol and physiological measurement.

primary_outcome.measure: Child self-reported pain: Wong-Baker Faces Pain Scale
primary_outcome.description: Pain outcomes are assessed by child himself or herself using Wong-Baker Faces Pain Scale. The scale includes 6 facial expressions with correlating numbers of 0-10 (0 being 'no hurt' and 10 being 'hurts worst'). Children pick a facial expression, that corresponds with their pain and see a number that matches it.

secondary_outcome.measure: Observer reported pain (parents): revised Faces, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability behavioral Pain Rating Scale (r-FLACC)
secondary_outcome.description: Pain outcomes are assessed by parents using the r-FLACC scale. The r-FLACC is a tool which evaluates pain-related behavior on facial expression, leg movement, activity, cry and consolability. Total score of the scale is summed in range 0 to 10. 0=relaxed and comfortable; 1-3=mild discomfort; 4-6=moderate pain; 7-10=severe pain.

secondary_outcome.measure: Observer reported pain (outcomes assessor ): revised Faces, Legs, Activity, Cry, Consolability behavioral Pain Rating Scale (r-FLACC)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after completing all participants' interventions.
secondary_outcome.description: The effectiveness is analyzed by outcomes assessors using r-FLACC via video taken during the procedure. The outcomes assessor is blind for the study design. The r-FLACC is a tool which evaluates pain-related behavior on facial expression, leg movement, activity, cry and consolability. Total score of the scale is summed in range 0 to 10. 0=relaxed and comfortable; 1-3=mild discomfort; 4-6=moderate pain; 7-10=severe pain.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediately after children reporting pain score.
secondary_outcome.description: Physiological stress levels are measured by means of salivary cortisol as an indicator. The salivary samples (1-2 milliliter) are taken with sterile collection devices immediately after children reporting pain score. The salivary samples are immediately stored at −20℃ freezer. Cortisol levels are determined by human salivary cortisol ELISA Kit (Jianglai, Shanghai, China).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the peripheral intravenous insertion procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluate the physiological response (heart rate) caused by peripheral intravenous puncture. A portable recording pulse oximeter is connected to children's index finger. Heart rate (beats per minute) is measured and recorded.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the peripheral intravenous insertion procedure.
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluate the physiological response (pulse oximetry) caused by peripheral intravenous puncture. A portable recording pulse oximeter is connected to children's index finger. Pulse oximetry（percentage）is measured and recorded.
Time (hours) from needle insertion to remove.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the peripheral intravenous catheter dwelling period.
secondary_outcome.description: Lidocaine cream side effect includes rash, edema and itching. Peripheral intravenous needle side effect includes phlebitis, infection, infiltration and unplanned extubation.

arm_group.description: Use compound lidocaine cream for the management of peripheral venipuncture pain.
Use psychological interventions (books, toy whistle, cartoon animation, breathing exercises, electronic products）for the management of peripheral venipuncture pain.
Use compound lidocaine cream combined with psychological interventions for the management of peripheral venipuncture pain.

intervention.description: Compound lidocaine cream will be applied on the skin surface of the injection site, 30 minutes prior to procedure. The dosage is 1g per square centimeter.

A trained play therapist will entertain and distract the child with psychological interventions (books, toy whistle, cartoon animation, breathing exercises, electronic products）starting 5 minutes before the procedure and ending when the child left the room after the procedure. Children can choose one or more.
Compound lidocaine cream combined with psychological interventions will be applied to the participants.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
Children aged 3-16 years receive first peripheral intravenous puncture during hospitalization.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Emergency peripheral intravenous puncture.
2. Allergic history for lidocaine cream.
3. Presence of cognitive impairment, hearing impairment or visual impairment.
4. Children who were discharged from the hospital after participating in the experiment but were readmitted due to illness.
5. Refused to participate in the study.
